title: Lev Kolinski
text:
My expertise is collaborative data science for international biological and human health research. I have led data curation and coding projects in my roles:
at Duke University:

I am the data scientist for a National Science Foundation Ecology and Evolution of Infectious Diseases grant, ‚ÄúMarket Integration, Land Use, and Pathogen Transmission in Rural Madagascar‚Äù
Oversee coding projects, data and code curation, and project management for researchers across the United States, Singapore, R√©union, and Madagascar

at EcoHealth Alliance

I worked as a researcher and project manager for a U.S. Department of Defense initiative, ‚ÄúReducing the threat of acute-febrile illness causing pathogens in Liberia‚Äù
Oversaw human and animal biological research across Liberia
Established automated data management systems to validate and curate survey and laboratory datasets
Trained Liberian researchers on data visualization

at the University of Michigan

I oversaw wild primate endocrinology research in Costa Rica (I speak Spanish!)
Curated and maintained longitudinal biological dataset with thousands of observations
Trained graduate students and field technicians in molecular laboratory methods and data analysis

title: Lev Kolinski
section: Some tools that have been particularly impactful for the teams I‚Äôve worked with:
text:
Some tools that have been particularly impactful for the teams I‚Äôve worked with:

Data validation dashboards
To foster collaborative data science with diverse teams including members without quantitative backgrounds, I generate dynamic and interactive Data Validation Dashboards using R, Java, CSS, and HTML. I have deployed these dashboards with great success in Liberia and Madagascar. These dashboards allow all team members to:

Track study progress as new data is collected and identify new samples to collect
Catch and revise data validation errors in real-time with automated queries
Access descriptive statistics and visualizations


















Project tracking in GitHub
To facilitate team coding projects for scientists of varying comfort levels with Git, I created a GUI project tracking dashboard for scientists on our international Ecology and Evolution of Infectious Diseases team. Team members can:

Track projects as they move from conceptualization to varying stages of publication
Assign other members to tasks related to specific projects
Easily access GitHub repositories for relevant projects


















Naming network automation
In social network analysis, researchers commonly deploy name-generating questions to develop an individual‚Äôs social network. To keep track of unique names, researchers often ask participants to provide phone numbers or email addresses of the people they name. In rural, remote contexts, though, individuals often do not have phones or internet, and they may provide names or nicknames with inconsistent spellings. Using methods from statistics and computer science, I created an automated tool to assign edges between individuals named in a social network. This tool:

Automatically cleans and standardizes name data provided in name-generating questions
Uses Jaro-Winkler and Jaccard algorithms to assign similarly spelled names to unique participant identification numbers (‚Äúsocial_netid‚Äù)
Generates dynamic network visualizations as new name data is added and unique individuals are assigned to nodes

title: Lev Kolinski
text:
Direct and indirect contact between humans and animals remain the most fundamental and modifiable drivers of cross-species pathogen transmission. Remarkably, though, we lack an understanding of what predicts these zoonotic interactions, particularly in rural contexts at the frontline of many zoonoses. We use graph modeling with network simulations to identify the drivers of human-animal contact and zoonotic interactions in rural Madagascar. This research allows us to use demographic traits to guide public health education interventions in resource-limited settings.





Co-led with Dr.¬†Camille DeSisto



Hookworms infect over half a billion people around the world. In resource-limited contexts, hookworm infection can be energetically draining; it may also regulate inflammation and cardiovascular disease risk. In this project, I use structural equation modeling to investigate the energetic and immunoregulatory pathways by which different hookworm species influence nutrition status and blood pressure to produce different health outcomes.








Disgust is hypothesized to be an evolved behavior to regulate avoidance of dangerous stimuli, especially pathogens. Yet, there is limited direct evidence that disgust actually improves fitness by promoting health behaviors that reduce exposures to parasites. I leverage Bayesian approaches with survey and laboratory data to model how disgust impacts viral exposures and immune activation.

title: Lev Kolinski
text:
I‚Äôm an evolutionary biologist and human ecologist fascinated with how evolutionary processes influence human well-being in changing environments. In my work, I leverage methods from infectious disease ecology, network science, computer science, and anthropology to understand social and biological determinants of health.
As a Ph.D.¬†candidate in Evolutionary Anthropology at Duke University, I investigate the dual burden of chronic and infectious disease in rural Madagascar. Some of my current research projects include predicting zoonotic disease exposure with network modeling; disentangling energetic and immunoregulatory pathways of hookworm infection and cardiovascular disease risk; investigating the adaptive value of disgust and pathogen avoidance behaviors. I advance this work through international collaborations involving laboratory, field, and computational methods.
I am passionate about data sovereignty, responsible AI, and collaborative data science. Prior to Duke, I led data curation and biological research as a scientist for a U.S. Department of Defense-funded initiative in Liberia in West Africa. Currently, in my role as data scientist for an NSF Ecology and Evolution of Infectious Diseases grant, I manage all data and coding projects for our international team across the United States, Singapore, R√©union, and Madagascar.
